description: A five-slide presentation with key information about the Ruby-throated Hummingbird.
title: All About the Ruby-throated Hummingbird

slides.title: Introduction to the Ruby-throated Hummingbird
slides.content: The Ruby-throated Hummingbird (Archilochus colubris) is a tiny migratory bird and the most common hummingbird species in eastern North America. Despite weighing only about as much as a penny, it undertakes remarkable long-distance migrations.

slides.title: Physical Characteristics
content: Males have a brilliant iridescent red throat (gorget) and emerald green back, while females lack the red throat.
They measure 2.8-3.5 inches in length with a wingspan of 3.1-4.3 inches and weigh only 2-6 grams.

slides.title: Flight and Feeding
content: Hummingbirds can hover in mid-air and fly backwards, forwards, and even upside down using figure-eight wing motions.
They feed primarily on nectar from flowers using their long, specialized tongues and supplement with insects and spiders.

slides.title: Migration and Navigation
content: Ruby-throated Hummingbirds migrate across the Gulf of Mexico in spring and fall, flying up to 500 miles non-stop.
They use the Earth's magnetic field, sun position, and visual landmarks to navigate during migration.

slides.title: Metabolism and Survival
content: Hummingbirds have the highest metabolism of any animal, with heart rates up to 1,260 beats per minute.
They enter a state called torpor at night to conserve energy, lowering their body temperature and metabolic rate significantly.
